Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Developed knowledge of basic procedures for solving linear ordinary differential equations and some partial differential equations. Improved analytical skills and application skills.
How to solve ordinary and partial differential equations

This is an awesome applied math course. Fair amount of work and the exams are pretty challenging, but you get a very solid grounding in the common methods of solving engineeeing problems (Laplace Transforms, Fourier, etc)
I learned how to solve first, second, and higher order differential equations, both ordinary and partial. I learned physical applications of these ideas as well.
I think I have a fairly decent understanding of how to solve differential equations although I don't think I completely understand how to apply them.
I learned methods of solving various types of linear differential equations.
I learned how to better approach and solve both partial and ordinary differential equations. I also improved my critical thinking skills and especially my study skills.
Learned how to solve a variety of differential equations through many methods
Intro to diff eq
An applied introduction to differential equations.
I learned how to solve linear differential equations.
Different methods for resolving differential equations
Pretty standard differential equations course, covering first and higher order ODEs and some PDEs
Solving differential equations, Laplace Transforms, Fourier Transforms, ODEs and PDEs
The course is very self-contained and follows the textbook closely. However, the topics are explained very quickly in class so it's hard to keep up, especially after reaching PDEs.

Strengths include the many available opportunities to get help. There were two different review sessions held every week and two different sets of office hours held every week as well. This was incredibly important for student learning and success in the course, as the teaching fellows who ran these review sessions were excellent and made the class so much easier to understand. Another strength was that the homework directly reflected the difficulty of the tests. Weaknesses included that lectures were not engaging and were often difficult to follow. Many times students were so confused that we didn't even know what questions to ask before the instructor moved onto the next topic.

The course material was not too difficult and can be used to understand processes in different subjects such as physics. Although the material wasn't impossible to learn, the lecture was not always the best place to learn it.
TAs were awesome. You need to get to know them and go to review sessions if you are going to do well.

Class is difficult and in many ways poorly taught. The teacher tries, but the course moves fast and the lectures can sometimes be unclear. A strength is that the professor stops to summarize core ideas, label things and where to find them in the textbook, and does many practice problems in order to help keep students who may be lost on track.
I felt that the problem sets were too focused on tedious details such as integration rather than applying the methods we actually learned in class. Otherwise the class was fine.

The material of the course is objectively difficult, and the lectures never actually covered how to solve differential equations-only derivations and proofs. The text book material was not in-depth enough to cover the course material that was tested on.
The lectures were sometimes confusing. Help was provided and available which is a strength.
Pretty standard enas math course

The beginning of the semester was clear, and the material of the course up to the second midterm was reasonable. After that the topics were not as clear, and the lectures did not help understand the material.
this course gives a decent introduction to differential equations but is limited by varying mathematical backgrounds of the students.

The lectures were pretty slow going but I feel like that's the case with any math class. The psets weren't too tough and the TA sessions were always very helpful if I had any questions. The material is extremely tough but it was also rewarding learning the stuff. We covered a large amount of material, which I think is good because the course taught me a lot.

This class's homework was not as hard as other QR classes I was taking, the p-sets were manageable. However, I don't feel that the class was well taught because the subjects were taught too fast and if I did not learn the material by myself, the lecture would not be so helpful
The class has many cool things to learn, but it is so fast paced, you get very little time to appreciate the beauty of the math. It becomes just a hustle to finish problem sets.

Diff Eq is always pretty hard to teach, but it would be awesome if the last part of the course could be slowed down. I really didn't get a lot out of PDEs, I still have a really surface understanding of them and think they really brought me down in the end.

Strengths -- instructor posts notes after class, which is helpful.

Weaknesses -- not enough time left for PDEs at the end. Moved too fast.
Would recommend for students who need to take differential equations, but would not recommend to those who want to gain an understanding of the "why's" behind solving problems.

I would recommend this course to another student who was interested in taking differential equations, as I think the set up of review sessions in addition to lecture made the material extremely understandable.
Yes. This course is doable.
Yes. Great course. Hui was efficient. TAs phenomenal. Plus you get out what you put in which is the mark of a great course.
I don't recommend it if you don't have to take it.
Not sure how it compares to the math department's version, but chances are if your taking diff eqs, its for your major.
I would only recommend this course to another engineering major who has no other option. If possible, take the equivalent in the math department.
Yup. You have to take it. Rough class but doable if you keep up with the content of the psets. Exams are fair, Final is rough.
This course is not very interesting but likely very applicable for higher level courses
Not necessarily, only if they have to for the major.
Yes, because it's helpful for your other engineering classes, at least that's what I've heard. No major knowledge of multivariable needed so you should be fine depending on who is teaching it.
Take it if you have to, but don't do it if you're just interested.

Not at all, actually. I like math, and in general I like understanding how things work. But this class was really boring tbh. But also it wasn't that hard. I think in previous years it used to be really hard, and she made it easier this year? Anyway, I felt like diff eqs was just a game of eye-spy-- see what kind of equation it is, then spit back the correct method to solve it. I guess it was kind of satisfying to get a better understanding of concepts that I had seen a little in physics or engineering , but overall it wasn't too inspiring.
